column11: Review Text
Not much here at all and we found it to be quite trashy and unclean. Not interesting and actually quite small. I would skip this as a waste of time.

column8: Stroll past the stalls at the Pettah Market!
column11: The floating market was a bit of faded glory.... better go a little further to the Pettah market, a big market where you mainly meet locals, I was about the only tourist. Wonderful to stroll past the stalls, everything is for sale and the market offers the typical Asian cosiness and chaos with ditto sounds and smells.

Had read about the market in Lonely Planet so made our way there only to find nasty green water that looked almost toxic, dilapidated bridges that require bravery to walk over (a little exaggerated but not by much!) and only a couple of shops. Really wasn't worth the effort to get there. Much better to go to the local market.
This is a run down market area with green smelly water surrounding it and a few sad shops and restaurants. I assume it was something good in the past but donâ€™t bother now.

column8: It is not worth a visit
column11: The Pettah Floating Market is a shopping destination located in the lively centre of Colombo, Sri Lanka, particularly in the Pettah district.  Located by the Beira Lake, the area was quite disappointing, as most of the shops were vacant and the lake's water appeared quite polluted.  The vacant store was quite unkempt as well.  It doesn't merit a visit.

Visited during a self-guided trip to Colombo.Expected something more , remembering the floating market in Bangkok. The Pettah Market is located on the island of Bastian Mawata and partly on the waters of Lake Beira right in the centre of Colombo. The organizers planned that the street vendors would move into concrete rows and visitors could, in addition to shopping, also ride on the lake in boats shaped like white swans. 92 shopping pavilions stretch along the canal with dirty water. Most of the pavilions are empty. The market was opened in 2014 and it was planned that its proximity to Colombo Fort railway station and bus station would make it in demand among tourists, but something went wrong and now it is a deserted and uninteresting place, which is not worth visiting.
Donâ€™t bother visiting. There is no market to see, just a pool of dirty water. This market should be removed from places to visit in Sri-Lanka
NOT a good idea. The range of markets is minimal, the stench from the surroundings was a lot to tolerate and the toilet facilities is an experience I really didnâ€™t need.

It is probably the only place in the country where you can sit and have a drink or eat something on a terrace, in this case next to the river,,, at a very good price, local price not tourist, there are umbrellas and tables,, on the very edge of the river, but it goes down very dirty, the place is full of shops... the truth is, a good place to rest a little...

It's true as previous reviews mentioned...this place is just not happening. I read an article about quick day trips during long layovers in Colombo. So we planned a quick visit here. There are only a handful of restaurants open and maybe 1 souvenir shop. We were highly disappointed. This place makes for some beautiful photos or a nice snack by the water. But don't waste your time as we did, driving across town for an hour to this place. There's some shopping areas nearby, the tower and some temples that you can walk or catch a short ride to. But the market here, sadly wasn't worth our time.
such a shame - just not happening !  as at April 2023 it has really wound down. i think we saw a couple of shops only -  half open
No idea if the place has lost its charm post Covid. But certainly when we went, there were very few stores. It wasn't as happening as they made it sound like.

Visited on 22nd February 2020 Recommended place to visit , this market on a water front and with visibility of the Lotus Tower provides some good photo options. the shops sell very basic stuff and prices are high. Very few people visit this place so the market was kind of deserted. Do give this place a miss if you are running short on time.

This is a pleasant enough place and there is room to stop and relax a little from the chaos.  It just lacks something, but I'm not quite sure what it is, but there is little atmosphere and almost a feeling that the place might fail and all the shops close up.  If you are in the area call in though.
This was one pathetic floating market. I pictured one like Bangkok but turned out to be like stalls near a waterway. Few handful shops. Others closed and others empty. Dont waste time going here.
when u think of floating market you would imagine vietnam but this place is just concrete shops. I would just give it 2.5/5 probably visit this place just for pictures and move on.
Pettah Floating Market is only good for a short walk. There were some shops open but not really interesting to see. I had a morning walk and had a light breakfast only.
Most of the shops are closed...if u are in this vicinity then go for a walk else this place can be skipped..

Almost every stores were empty. There were no other people, no great atmosphere. It reminds of an extinct area. You can take a very short walk close to the water, but the distance is not long either. We do not recommend this in any case!

We visited the Pettah Floating Market this morning, both very much looking forward to it. The market was practically deserted and what stores were open were selling cheap, tacky products. Very disappointing on what could be an excellent market.

For a relatively new attraction, Pettah hasn't fared very well at all. It seems like the local market has relocated to the car park outside what is supposed to be the floating market and all that is left is a couple of small cafe's and lots of empty stalls. Don't waste your time.
This is not a floating market.Its board only floating market.There are small shops here nothing much it's better to skip.

A place made for tourist which failed miserably. Half the shops are closed with a few open with not interesting products. The local market next to this area is definitely a place to go if you want a very local feel of the area. Traders and wholesalers are busy with their chores. Nothing more authentic than this. Best to wander into the small alleys to find that you are the only foreigner around, but that provided the best experience of a local market.

This is not a real floating market just a few shops on water. They have the Swan boat where you can cycle around the water but it's a small pond, it's uninteresting to do. There's not much shops so we picked I think the second shop on the right. We ordered orange Juice and 2 flavor ice cream (Chocolate + Vanilla). The orange juice was aweful, it's diluted and filled with sugar. The ice cream is equally horrible, it was already melting and the taste is aweful. Let's just say the chocolate don't taste like chocolate and the vanilla don't taste like vanilla. I never had such an aweful ice cream in my life. And the vanilla had raisins, YEK YEK YEK!

No idea if it has changed since previous reviews, but there were no boats on the water and no market items. This presented as a fixed group of shops over the water selling cheap, throw away items. We had lunch there which was very good as it was made fresh to order. The watermelon juice was exceptional as were the noodles. Prices were cheap. Thereâ€™s nothing wrong with this place but itâ€™s a group of shops, built next to the water, not a floating market.

The market is located near the Colombo Fort Railway Station. It is located around a water body. The market appears to have been developed, especially by keeping the tourist in mind. However, there are not many popular tourist places around, so the market remains mostly deserted. We visited the market in the evening, around the sunset time. There are many shops, but most of them were closed. There were few restaurants, which were open, but with very few patrons.
Empty place. Some shops were open but no guests... a few restaurants had some tourists. It was on the way to my destination so I enjoyed to take a walk. Nothing special.
Went for a lunch. Better place compared to the places around pettah. Due to lack of maintenance of the water surrounding the market, there was a bad smell.
Only a few shops open and not worth your time or the tuk tuk fair. One clothing store and the rest food shops. Mostly vacant buildings.
Went there expecting more. Most shops were either closed or vacant. Nice concept but very few people in attendance.
This floating market is established on a bridge located above the bustling beira lake. You can buy fruits, vegetables, electronics, footwear, bags, accessories etc.

Where to even start?! We went on a Sunday which is a quiet day as we were told not all shops would be open. Did we notice? NO!! This is one busy market, non stop hustle & bustle. Endless amount of shops and everything you can imagine here. We were looking for leather shoes, handbag, and produce. Found everything we were looking for but my advice is this...if you know what you are wanting, ask someone where you might find it or you could be walking for hours! Wear light appropriate clothing, comfortable footwear, and bring bottled water. You will find a mix of quality items from leather to to fake leather. As is with the jewelry, as I noticed most said gold plated. Prices are very good but not all vendors will bargain with you. They told us a price and he wouldn't go any lower and actually let us leave his shop without coming down in price!!We did eventally go back and buy the shoes because they were a fantastic deal anyway. We will be going back! Oh! As a side note, a produce vendor offered us samples of his fruit without us asking, so nice.

This was obviously designed to be a nice shopping area next to the bustling market. Half the shops are empty the other half are grubby and full of headphones and scratched knockoff sunglasses. Don't bother wasting your time.

The floating market is an effort by the Urban Development Authority to turn Colombo (or at least the area) into a green city. Perhaps they took it literally. The pond, on which the market is floating on, gives off sewerage vibes. The water was thick and green... I can't even venture to think the nasty things floating in the water. The area smelled like sewer. There were water fountains and I prayed the wind wouldn't blow while I was walking as I'd be showered by the green water. There were only a couple of shops which were open, and I wouldn't recommend buying anything displayed outside as they might have been sprayed by the green water at some point.
This is an interesting place to walk in for a stroll. However, it should not be considered a shopping destination for most tourists in Colombo
for the 1st time we got experience by visiting this floating market in Colombo. Very busy area in early morning. Can buy lot of fresh foods from there.
There were only a couple of shops actually open. It was a bit pitiful. But the surroundings were beautiful.

We enjoyed our visit to the â€˜floating marketâ€™ although it was very quiet with quite a lot closed, we enjoyed half an hour sitting in the shade of a cafe here, cooling off with a cold drink and a lovely view of the lake! Definitely worth incorporating in to an afternoon stroll around the busy and bustling Pettah! The drinks were also very reasonably priced for the location.
Novel market set on floating pontoons. It's really just another market, but worth a photo for its different setting.
Floating Market is a very beautiful place in Colombo City. It has a lot of restaurant and food corners

It was still an hour before catching my bus from Colombo so i headed to the Floating Market which is east of the station. There are a few souvenir shops here and places to eat. I saw one solitary pelican on the pond while seated at a table enjoying a cool drink. If you want a quiet place in the center of the city  this would be one of the places to go.. This seemed to be a place that attracts young courting couples.
Boring ... Do something else instead ... Nearby the busstation, the close early. Simple food you can eat here ... Fountains not working, bit dirty ...

In the midst of the busyness in Pettah wholesale and flea market, the Pettah Floating Market is a place where you can find a little "refuge" in the midst of madness. A good place to sit down and relax and have a decent lunch whilst looking through some local clothings.
Itâ€™s not easy to find a relaxing place after walking the wholesales and flea market opposed ! This place is definitely good for a break like lunch! Quiet and simple .

Basically don't waste time coming to this place. A few traders, poor quality overpriced clothing, nothing whatsoever to recommend it. There are far more interesting places to visit nearby such as Maning Markets just down the road. Large restaurant, no toilets.
For us a nice place to relax due to the fact when we were here almost no other person joined that location.
The Pettah Floating Market in Colombo is a good place to visit for some cheap and budget items however I prefer outside

I read all the reviews on tripadvisor but my daughter felt that we needed to see the floating market for ourselves. What a waste of time - not one tourist there, the food stalls looked terrible and unhygienic, more than 60% of the shops were empty, unkept premises with dirty green water, dilapidated just terrible PLEASE DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME TO VISIT THE Pettah Floating Market!!

Although a nice try to build an attractive shopping place just outside the very hectic local market just close to the bus station , it is not worthwhile to go to this place.  Half of the little shops are empty and what is left is nothing special.  Pity as the location could have been nice.
Had a great time and many more things to buy. many shops with various attractive goods which are little bit of higher prices
This market is located south from the Old City of Colombo next to the main road. It is surely an interesting tourist attraction.

The majority of the stalls are empty, it's very run down and has a real air of desperation about it. It isn't worth the visit. We visited looked and left it took 10 minutes also the water is stagnant and you will need to be well covered with Deet to ward off the mozzies.

The Pettah Floating Markets are located at Pettah, in Colombo and consist of large number of trade stalls, which sells electronics, clothes, shoes, jewelry, fast-food, vegetables and fruits etc. There are some stalls also established on boats on the Lake. The floating market serves as a tourist attraction selling mainly local products and local handicrafts. The space is a lot of clean wooden boards, grey floors and red terracotta tiles. Itâ€™s good to roaming around to pass some leisure time at the evening.
There are few local / Chinese food restaurant placesâ€‹. Cleaness is a ? If you are interest to visit, look floating market from distance.

This was build after demolishing very ugly landscape. Now, there are some food and other stalls with better view point. However, present government has not put enough effort to maintain this location.
Its a nice medium sized hangout place with restaurant and market. There is also boating available at a bargain-able price.
Poorly maintained by the local government. potential place and how beautiful is this place. so sad to see its not been maintained
One of a kind floating market in Colombo. Seems like they create one to replica the one in Thailand. However, maintainance is required. Quite a lot of empty shop lots and facilities are quite old.

This is a market built on stilts in a canal water. A busy rail line passes just behind this place. Originally meant for selling local produce and crafts. Even now you can get some cheap local cuisine and curios. It is a nice location, but looks a bit neglected. Can surely go back to its glory days with some effort.

Few years back it was a really nice place and crowed with shops. Now it is almost deserted. Few shops are remaining. No more floating shops. Only few restaurants get some visitors. It is a nice, peaceful lacation in the evening. During day time it is too hot. If authorities take some trouble to make improvements it is a very good place to visit, have a evening tea and rest Entrance is free. It is located near the Pettah private bus stand.
Definitely not worth the trip to the floating market. Totally deserted with no shops or markets. An absolute waste of time.

Cons: -the name is deceiving. The market isn't floating at all, its built on land, right beside a small river. - the name is also deceiving because it isn't much of a market- there were only a few shops selling clothes and that is all. The amount of shops available there is VERY little. Do not come here expecting to shop! Pros: -the only reason you should come here is for maybe a drink by the river which is really a nice green colour and maybe some birdwatching as there are pelicans in the river. You can also take a pedalboat arouns the driver but i repeat, do NOT come here for shopping!!!! -it is quite a peaceful location as there is alot of space and you can just sit there and watch the birds in the river and there is a traintrack next to the market also. Its near the main road, but the river separates the mainroad from the market hence its a quiet getaway from the hustle and bustle of Colombos streets
Nothing much so see here. The place and the lakes is nice. But many empty shops and almost no crowds

I guess the other reviews are correct. There really is no Floating Market. Right behind it however, is a train yard with some of the coolest box cars I've ever seen. Not for nothin, I really enjoyed them. Really old stuff! I'll add pictures when I get them organized.
It was a nice place but the shop owners are annoying as usual. ðŸ˜‚ but its really nice to have place like this in the heart of the city..
I went there just looking for a fridge magnet and I didn't find nothing. There are a lot of stores empties and close. Definitely don't waste your time going there

Most stalls were shut, about 5 in the whole strip were open on a Friday afternoon. One shop sold some cotton t-shirts  but they were overpriced. The markets across the road were buzzing, but not with souvenirs, mostly fabric, some junk jewellery and old clothes/shoes. A local market, not a craft market. Down the road a few hundred metres on the same side as the floating markets, now THAT was a good market!!! Go straight there  and bargain down 30%

I brought my wife to this market the for the first time. She had a blast and enjoyed walking around and exploring the area. She was quite impressed by the local food and fruit markets. Just be vigilant when walking around as you are sharing the roads with everything and anything.

We walked quite a distance to see what was going to be a floating market similar to the ones in Thailand.  But it was just a lot of little stands selling local merchandise on the side of the river.  I am not sure what was floating other than trash.  I think there were grand ideas that went into the planning of the market, but they just didn't materialize.

It might have been a floating market once but now it's just a canal with a few shops a cafes on one side. The place is a nice quiet island in the loud city close to the bus station which makes it a good area to relax while waiting for your bus. The shops are of very little interest but the cafes are nice. I had my best Kottu in one of the small places there, it was ridiculously cheap yet so huge I could hardly finish it. The only reason why I give this place 3 stars and not 2 is because this meal I had here. If you have limited time in Colombo you can avoid this place as it adds nothing to your Sri Lankan experience but if you need to catch the bus to Galle or Negombo, etc then it's worth a few minutes of detour.

We happened upon the floating market by accident as we were on a packed bus and desperate to get off. Had a meal in a small cafe here which was freshly prepared and cost around Â£1 each. The food was really good. We are vegetarians so only tried vegetable noodles and vegetable khottu. Both were lovely.  Didn't see anything in the way of a floating market though.

I ideal place to have a rest and refreshments when arriving to Colombo, from long distance travel. Almost all outstation private buses,  terminate beside of the Floating Market. This is simply small water park, all the building are on water. (But not floating) However most of food outlet and shop are not rented. You can see lot of local young couple engorging and relaxing Food and cheap at self-service outlets. Although the place designed targeting Sri Lanka Locals, it is good place for foreign tourist to have relaxation after long journey, till they catch  the next bus to leave next destination. adjoining bus station as well as Railway station is the hub for all destinations of  Sri Lanka and also to Airport (Colombo- CMB). Toilet facilities are not available  within the premises, after waling long distance you have to cross the main road, to use Bus station toilets. The toilets are not well cleaned for the stranded for a foreigner, Only average level.
Most of the stalls were closed or selling things of little interest,  I wouldnt regard it as a must see ... perhaps a 5 minute stroll coming from somewhere else.

Do not compare to Bangkok floating market otherwise one will be disappointed. Nothing much around expected for lots of little drink shops , clothing shops not selling anything special . When we sat down for a drinks there was an amazing cool breeze that was really pleasant after the heat and smell and pollution of diesel  from walking through buses & pettah market .

More of a tourist attraction than a huge market place, on a Sunday, this place was mostly empty with a few students and couples huddled under sun umbrellas for a conversation. If you're in the vicinity, you could stroll around this place - not worth going here specifically to see the market, unless there's an event happening here.

Near to Fort railway station. It's a place for try local food , fresh fruit juice and also look around. there are not so expensive, chicken fried rice is just 250 rupees (1.7 US$). Good place for relaxation

The concept of good but great. Still I can't consider this as a "Floating Market". Yet I would consider this as a "Market by the Canal" If you are around Petta or Colombo Fort, better visit this place. Can recommend the Restaurant in the middle of the Canal

This place is located near to Fort railway station. Good place for a small gathering and to have a quick shopping or to have meals. I have visited recently with my friends. Its not crowded like other places in Pettah.

This may have been a great destination and attraction at one point, but it's clearly seen better days and appears to be on its way down. We expected it to be really crowded, but it was actually fairly empty. There are quite a few merchants still selling wares in shops, but we didn't see to many customers except for the food stalls and restaurants. Can pay separately to boat in the water. That being stated, the nighttime pictures are wonderful!

well i'm thankful to the government for clearing the canal but the algae is the canal may never disappear. I don't think its hygienic to dine there. I might puke if i eat from there. My suggestion is ...Please don't go there to eat anything cos the view is terrible.

A wonderful idea but saÃ¬ finesse and just copy pasting without an iota of an idea on the ground situation. Only three to four eateries and pimped and propelled by all unsavoury characters due to no security officers being present. Needs attention, vÃ¢rietyand security.
This is next to central bus stand fort. Having few food outlets and clothing outlets. This was well maintain few months back, but now it's not.

Due to Surprising reasons, this market situated sideways of the busy Pettah Bus stand, is crowded by few people and not a large market either. But will be a good source for travellers who just await a Bus at the Main Bus Terminals arouns Pettah and has some time to see around and buy some essentials.
No Point of Going there,It was good when it starts.but now not like that.but you can just walk there.
Not like floating market in Thailand , this stands still !!!nothing much to buy if your a tourist cheap tack !!!

I went to the Floating Market for a bite one day and discovered a lovely range of shops selling clothes and also restaurants, it is an amazing place considering its isolated and secluded location in the Pettah .
This was one of the hot places of Colombo fort. It is pretty sad to see that the government or the Colombo municipality just letting the place to ruin.
The vision for this project must go to the Rajapaksa regime. Who developed this into such a nice place. It was a mess in the past. Now very interesting to walk along.

Floating market is a great idea for Colombo. There are food stalls, artificial jewelries, cloths.. Also there are benches to have a chat.. However, it is hard to find a empty place, because you have to compete with lovers..

Finally after long water this addition given some beauty to the Colombo fort area and its great specially to just relax from the buzy city in Colombo. at the begin it was good but now its not properly maintain even the wash rooms were closed up. Floating restaurant service some foods, snack and drink lacks quality and service though, this has good potential to get crowds and foreigners given its the center and all busses, trains come there all we need to do is take care of the attraction properly.
This is one of the Main Roads which also runs along the floating market. There are are some small houses and a market which floats on water, Nothing much.

I really enjoyed the setting of this small market beside a small lake. I'm not sure if the lake is man made or not but it was very nice, although the water was super dirty. There are some nice shops selling clothing and souvenirs at fairly reasonable prices but I'd recommend that you buy these from Pettah market. It had a variety of food outlets that didn't look very clean. So it is better just to visit and take some nice pictures rather than anything else.
A pleasant walk along the boardwalk next to some water is always restful after the bustle of the city but the shops are very touristy and pricey.

Built to pacify a tired traveller this area provides many to the Public Transport Traveller. Short distance from the busy and noisy Private Bus stand this provide rest to any who requires rest at no cost. Police security is available 24/7 but better to be careful with Colombo pickpockets and Thieves. Some days the area is smelly due to 'Algae' growth in the lake. Food and other facilities are available to refresh before embarking on another journey.

Located on a canal near Beira Lake, next to the main Colombo Bus Station. The name is a bit deceptive as none of the market stalls are actually floating on the water. Essentially there a series of stalls alongside a boardwalk, which runs along the waters edge. The stalls sell clothing, luggage and electronics, with a number of food and juice shops. There is nothing unique about the products sold at the Pettah Floating Market but it's waterside setting is different from the other street markets. It should only take 20mins to slowly walk from one end to the other. There are a number of swan pedal boats you can hire but the green colour of the water may put most foreign tourists from giving them a try. Given that it's located very close to the chaotic busy traditional Pettah markets, if you are in the area it's a good place to start or finish a Pettah Market experience.
A couple of shops alongside a lake , different touristy place to spend an hour. You get stuff that is not of great quality. I bought some fruit and spices
Nothing but overpriced stuff you can. Find all over Sri Lanka. Don't let the guidebooks or online guides fool you. Please skip.

Pettah floating market is one of the latest attractions in Colombo fort and is something new to the country. Gets very crowded during evenings and sometimes difficult to find parking. A nice place to hang around if you visit Fort area

We were dropped by the floating markets by our tuk-tuk. The train line runs directly behind the market and it is positioned in the middle of the canal. There aren't too many market stalls here, so doesn't take long to walk around. Nice cafe at the entrance for a cold drink to escape the heat.

The place used to be well-maintained during the previous government but the present government doesn't seem to be paying much attention to these tourist attractions. Anyway, it's not attractive now as it used to be. I think this place needs to be paid a little extra attention as this could be an awesome experience for the ones who are touring in Colombo.
A nice stop by in colombo tour. Although the markets have diminished but this place is still good to look at and have a walk around.

Pettah floating market is not really  floating. It is built in the Baire lake in and elevated platform. Many people visited it at the beginning for the curiosity. But it faded away due to lot of reasons. One is that entrance is through a road crowded with buses due to it is a main bus station. Two â€“ market does not sell anything unique and stuff is available in any part of adjoining flea market at Pettah for the same or less prices. Three â€“ lake water gets so stinky that one would not think of eating there.
I visited this Place on Eid Holiday so it was close. but can assume that must be beautiful when fountains and lighting are on. Have Heard good about shopping and Boating..

Although this place is called the Floating market it does not float like in other countries, but it is situated surrounded by The Beira lake. This place has many restaurants & shops with a variety of stuff for sale. The place has not been maintained well due to lack of customers. People enjoyed visiting this place at first due to its novel idea. Good for relaxation, as the place is comparatively cheap, compared to city prices. Good for Budget travelers.
